metadata.title: The influence of support in the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate by Cu-based catalysts

The influence of support in the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate by Cu-based catalysts Jeong-Kwang Nam Myoung-Jae Choi Deug-Hee Cho Jeong-Kwon Suh Seong-Bo Kim ⁎ Environment & Resource Research Center, Korea Research Institute of Chemical Technology (KRICT), Sinseongno 19, Yuseong, Daejeon 305-600, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 42 860 7555; fax: +82 042 860 7268. Graphical abstract Highlight ► Among various metal catalysts, copper chloride showed the highest activity and selectivity of DMC among Mg, Ca, Co and Fe containing chlorides. ► Copper chloride and copper bromide, having strong electron withdrawing power provided high yields of DMC. ► Y-zeolite yielded the best results on conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC among various support. ► The addition of alkali metal hydroxides increased the conversion and selectivity. The effects of various anions containing copper based catalysts were studied in regard to the preparation of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) through oxidative carbonylation of methanol under a liquid phase system. A copper compound providing the strong withdrawing power of halides as anion yielded excellent results with respect to the conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC. However, copper homogenous catalysts suffer from separation of the catalyst after reaction. Thus, the development of a new reaction system using various supports including Y-zeolite was attempted. The conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC were affected by the properties of the supports. In particular, Y-zeolite showed the best yield among various supports. The influence of various promoters was examined with the aim of increasing the yield of DMC from methanol. The yield of DMC was increased with the addition of alkali metal in the order Li+ <Na+ <K+, but with selectivity in the order of Li+ >Na+ >K+, respectively. Various analyses were conducted in order to elucidate these results. From a XRD analysis, the existence of crystal forms of copper chloride hydroxide of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) was observed. We confirmed the presence of peaks of CuO in Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C). The CO-TPD analysis revealed that CO desorption is an important step to determine the formation of DMC. The addition of NaOH as a co-catalyst resulted in a lower desorption temperature of carbon monoxide in Cu catalyst. Also, XPS analysis results showed that Cu+ on the calcined Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalyst was formed by the reduction of Cu2+. XANES results provided the difference of reactivity according to the state of the copper catalyst. Activity of this reaction in terms of DMC yields, obtained in the order of CuCl2 >Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry)>Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C)>Cu(OH)2 was in accordance with the maximum peak of the low photon energy position. Keywords Dimethyl carbonate Oxidative carbonylation of methanol Heterogeneous catalyst Cu/Y-zeolite Promoter 1 Introduction Dimethyl carbonate (DMC) has been attracting attention due to its usage in environmental compounds. In particular, it can be used as a methoxycarbonylation agent in place of phosgene for the production of polycarbonates and polyurethane [1]. DMC has also been used as a fuel additive due to its high oxygen content of 53%. It is also being considered as an environmentally friendly alternative to MTBE (methyl tert-butyl ether) [2]. The demand for DMC is thus growing rapidly as raw materials of polycarbonate and polyurethane resin manufacturing, medicine and pesticide intermediates in the synthesis and electronic components industries, and fine chemicals and automotive industries. Conventionally, DMC has been synthesized by reacting phosgene with methanol. This method, however, leads to several problems related to toxicity and corrosiveness due to the usage of phosgene [3,4]. (1) 2CH3OH+COCl2 →(CH3O)2CO+2HCl The new DMC processes without the inclusion of phosgene such as the oxidative carbonylation of methanol (Enichem, Italy) [5], methylnitrite process (Ube, Japan) [6], ester exchange process (Bayer, Germany), vapor oxidative carbonylation of methanol (Dow, USA) [7] and direct synthesis of methanol and carbon dioxide have been developed. (2) 2CH3OH+CO+1/2O2 →(CH3O)2CO+H2O Copper chloride catalyst is an excellent catalyst for the synthesis of DMC by COCl2, the reaction is delineated in Eq. (1). However, it suffers from problems of corrosion of the reactor and difficulty of use. Thus, new catalyst systems using a supported copper catalyst have been investigated in efforts to resolve these problems. Copper catalysts using various supports such as zeolite and activated carbon for the oxidative carbonylation of methanol have been investigated [8–10]. Previous studies have shown that the structure and chemical composition of the zeolite influence the activity and selectivity of Cu-exchanged zeolite [11–13]. In the present study, reaction factors such as the effects of various metals, anion combined with copper, supports and promoters were investigated. Evaluation of catalytic activity and a detailed characterization of alkali metal promoted Cu/Na/support were also performed. Various alkali metal promoters were added to the Cu/Y-zeolite in order to enhance the conversion of methanol and the selectivity of DMC. Morphological analyses by XRD and CO-TPD measurement were conducted in order to establish a fundamental understanding of the relationship between the catalytic performance and the nature of active sites in the copper supported catalysts. Analyses of the oxidation state of the copper catalyst by XPS and XANES were conducted in order to elucidate the effects of supports and promoters for DMC formation. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of catalysts CuCl2/alkali (alkali-earth) metal hydroxide/zeolite catalysts were prepared by CuCl2·2H2O (Aldrich, 99.0%), alkali or alkali-earth hydroxides (LiOH, NaOH, KOH, Mg(OH)2, Ca(OH)2) and commercial Y-zeolite in its NH4 form (ZEOLYST, Si/Al=5.1). In preparing the catalysts, copper chloride was first dissolved in distilled water and, in rapid succession, NH4-Y zeolite was added. Next, an alkali or alkali-earth metal hydroxide (LiOH, NaOH, KOH, Mg(OH)2, Ca(OH)2) solution was added under stirring at 363K. Water was removed by heating, and drying was carried out for 12h at 383K. The sample was calcined for 2h at 823K for 2h in an air atmosphere. 2.2 Characterization of catalysts The X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out using a Rigaku diffractometer (model D/Max-2200V). The working voltage and current for the analysis were 40kV and 40mA. Cu Kα (λ =1.5418Å) was used as the light source. The sample was held to the holder and was scanned from 3° to 60° at a rate of 5°/min. The temperature-programmed desorption of the carbon monoxide (CO-TPD) experiment was performed to determine the carbon monoxide desorption capacity. CO-TPD analysis was performed on an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics, USA). The sample was first degassed at 473K under helium flow (10ml/min) for 2h. After degassing, the temperature of the sample was maintained at 323K. 10% CO/He (flow rate=50cm3/min) was then introduced to the sample cell to allow the sample to absorb the carbon monoxide. After the adsorption, the temperature of the sample was raised from 323 to 673K at a rate of 5K/min. The carbon monoxide released from the sample, as a consequence of the temperature rise, was continuously monitored by a thermal conductivity detector. The temperature-programmed desorption of the ammonium (NH3-TPD) experiment was performed to determine the acidity capacity. A NH3-TPD analysis was performed on an Autochem 2920 (Micromeritics, USA). The sample was first degassed at 473K under a helium flow (10ml/min) for 2h. After degassing, the temperature of the sample was maintained at 323K. 15% NH4/He (flow rate=50cm3/min) was then introduced to the sample cell to allow the sample to absorb the ammonium. After the adsorption, the temperature of the sample was raised from 323 to 973K at a rate of 5K/min. The ammonium released from the sample, as a consequence of the temperature rise, was continuously monitored by a thermal conductivity detector. The surface composition and state of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) obtained with an AXIS NOVA (KRATOS, UK). An Al Kα electron source was used with a power setting of 150W. The state and coordination of Cu in Cu/Na/Y-zeolite was determined by a Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge analysis (XANES), which was carried out in transmission mode at the Pohang Accelerator Laboratory (PAL) on beamline 7-C1. The energy was calibrated by the distinct peak at the Cu K-edge of a Cu foil as 8980.3eV. Cu XANES data were analyzed with the IFEFFIT package. 2.3 Performance of catalytic activities An activity test for prepared catalysts was carried out in an autoclave system (Fig. 1 ). The prepared catalysts were inserted in an autoclave (hastelloy, 100cm) with methanol (CH3OH, SK chemical, 99.95%). Ar (99.99%) was purged 2–3 times at a pressure of 2.3bar. After the purging, O2 (99.99%) 15bar (0.05mole) and CO (99.95%) 65bar (0.215mole) were injected to the reactor, and the reactor heated up. DMC synthesis reaction was performed with a constant stirring speed for 4h in a batch system. After cooling, Ar (99.99%) was purged 2–3 times at a pressure of 2.3bar and the products were filtered through membrane filters (Whatman, 0.2μm TF). Analysis was carried out by GC (DS 6200, FID detector with HP-1 column). Methanol conversion was calculated from the product balance taking into account the formation of DMC, DMM and DME. The product selectivity was calculated referring to the particular product concentration at the reactor outlet to the percentage of methanol converted. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of the anion species contained in the Cu catalyst Various metal chloride catalysts were studied with respect to the conversion of methanol and the selectivity to DMC. As shown in Table 1 , among various metal catalysts, copper chloride showed higher activity and selectivity in DMC synthesis than chloride catalysts containing Mg, Ca, Co and Fe, respectively. With use of the copper chloride catalyst, conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC was 61.8% and 97.4%. Copper catalysts containing different anions were examined in terms of the conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC. Table 2 shows that Cu2+ provided higher yields of DMC than Cu+ and copper catalysts containing chlorine and bromine gave high conversion and selectivity. These results are attributed to the strong withdrawing power of the halides. The most commonly employed of the covalent compounds included metal chloride are employed as Lewis acid catalysts. Copper chloride is formed catalysts by accepting an electron from the donor molecule. Recently, the new experiment results were obtained. As shown in Table 3 , formation of DMC was affected by the addition order of O2 and CO. If you changed the order of addition, the yields of DMC significantly decreased. This result shows that the oxidation state of copper catalyst is a very important factor in this reaction system. Tables 2 and 3 show that oxidation state of copper catalyst had a significant influence on both the reactivity of methanol and selectivity to DMC. Many researchers have studied the mechanism underlying this [14,15] and it has been reported that the reactions proceeds via two separate steps. The first step is oxidation to form cupric methoxychloride. Methanol is first adsorbed molecularly on the copper catalyst. After adsorption, when oxygen is present in the reaction mixture, the adsorbed methanol forms a methoxide species. (3) 2CH3OH+1/2O2 +2Cu+Cl− →2(CH3OCu)+Cl− +H2O The second step entails the reduction of the cupric methoxychloride with carbon monoxide to form DMC. The insertion of CO to cupric methoxide forms a carbomethoxide. King reported that methoxide species on the surface resulted in DMC formation with carbon monoxide. On the basis of IR spectroscopy results, King [16] reported that this CO insertion is the rate determining step. Here, the increased charge density on Cu+ results in greater back donation of charge to the π-bonding orbital of CO. (4) (CH3OCu)+ Cl− +CO→(CH3O)2CO+2Cu+Cl− If the chloride ions in the above reaction did not participate in the redox cycle of copper, the same redox cycle could be carried out using various Cu/support(Su−) as shown below (5) 2CH3OH+1/2O2 +2Cu+Su− →2(CH3OCu)+Su− +H2O The second step here is to reduce the cupric methoxychloride with carbon monoxide to form DMC: (6) (CH3OCu)+Su− +CO→(CH3O)2CO+2Cu+Su− 3.2 Heterogenization of copper chloride As shown in the previous result, the copper catalyst containing anions having strong drawing power showed more activity in the formation of DMC than the copper catalyst containing anions having an electron donating group. In particular, CuCl2 having two chlorides, displayed the highest activity on the formation of DMC. However, CuCl2 is a homogeneous catalyst that is difficult to recover from the reaction mixture and causes corrosion of the reactor. Thus, new heterogeneous catalyst systems using supports have been explored by many researchers [17,18]. In the present work, copper catalysts were calcined in order to reduce the dissolution of CuCl2 during the reaction. However, the yield of DMC was very low, as shown in Table 4 . Among various supports, Y-zeolite having an acidic property, presented the highest DMC yield. This shows that an acidic copper catalyst activates oxidative carbonylation of methanol in DMC synthesis. 3.3 Effect of promoter on DMC synthesis The activity on the calcined Cu/support catalysts was considerably lower than that of the homogenous Cu catalyst. To elucidate the low reactivity of the calcined Cu/support catalysts, we examined the use of alkali or alkali-earth metal hydroxides as a promoter. Among various alkali metals, Cu/Na/Y-zeolite exhibited the most outstanding activity as shown in Table 5 . As shown in Table 5, the addition of alkali or alkali-earth metal hydroxides increased the conversion and selectivity more relative to the reference case without a promoter. The yield of DMC on the alkali metal was increased in the order of Li+ <Na+ <K+, but the selectivity was increased in the order of Li+ >Na+ >K+. The addition of NaOH showed the best DMC yield, 39.1%. The Na/Cu molar ratio in the Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalysts appears to be closely related with the catalyst performance. Table 6 shows the activity changes on the Na/Cu molar ratio. The Na/Cu molar ratio was varied from 0.0 to 2.0. With an increase of the molar ratio (Na/Cu) in the Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalysts, the catalytic activities were increased within a range of Na/Cu molar ratio of 1.0. Methanol conversion was increased from 16.5 to 36.8% and 42.7%. DMC selectivity was also increased from 79.2 to 87.6% and 91.5% with an increase of the Na/Cu molar ratio. In particular, methanol conversion and DMC selectivity showed maximum values at a Na/Cu molar ratio of 1.0. 3.4 Influence of various supports The characteristics of Cu/Na/supports are compared in Table 7 . The addition of NaOH to the other supports had an impact on the activity of the DMC. Y-zeolite showed excellent yields in the formation of DMC. The result that Y-zeolite provided an excellent reactivity of methanol and selectivity to DMC can be explained by the formation of Lewis acid sites from the calcinations of Y-zeolite. Ward reported that thermal dehydroxylation of Brönsted acid sites could be expected with the formation of Lewis acidity. It was reported that Lewis acid sites were formed at temperatures as high as 750°C and were not reconverted into Brönsted acid sites by adding water [19]. The increase of DMC yield was attributed to activation of the copper catalyst by these forming Lewis acid sites, same as chlorine in CuCl2. 3.5 Characteristics of calcined Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalyst Various prepared catalysts were compared on the preparation of DMC. The results of various catalysts showed the difference of reactivity for the state of copper catalyst. Activity on the DMC yield of CuCl2 >Cu/Na/Y-zeolite(dry)>Cu/Na/Y-zeolite(calcined)>Cu(OH)2 as seeing in Table 8 . These catalysts were analyzed by various methods to understand the experimental results. 3.5.1 EDS or XRD analysis To understand the effect of NaOH addition on the Cu/Y-zeolite catalyst, various analyses were performed. Dried Cu/Na/Y-zeolite and calcined Cu/Na/Y-zeolite were analyzed by EDS, and the results are presented in Fig. 2 . The results of the analysis reveal that the amount of chlorine was largely reduced during the calcinations of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite. Nitrogen in the form of ammonia was evaporated during the calcinations. Various Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalysts were analyzed by XRD. Fig. 3 shows X-ray diffraction patterns on NaCu/Y-zeolite catalysts prepared at different calcination temperatures. This result shows that numerous peaks of copper chloride hydroxides (Cu2(OH)3Cl) were detected at the dried NaCu/Y-zeolite catalyst. As a result of a detailed investigation on copper chloride hydroxide peaks in XRD patterns, the existence of crystal forms of copper chloride hydroxide peaks was observed. According to the JCPDS reference files, this is γ-Cu2(OH)3Cl (paratacamite, JCPDS #19-0389). This result was similar to an experiment in which Han et al. [9] reported the data of the XRD pattern in CuCl2/NaOH/AC. However, calcined NaCu/Y-zeolite catalyst was not observed in copper chloride hydroxides (Cu2(OH)3Cl) peaks. The XRD pattern difference between the before and after calcinations was confirmed. However, the status of copper could not be precisely confirmed after calcinations. This result shows that Cu2(OH)3Cl does not give an effect on the formation of DMC. 3.5.2 NH3-TPD and CO-TPD The acidic characteristic of various Cu/Na/support catalysts was confirmed through NH3-TPD experiments. Cu/Na/Y-zeolite showed the presence of a larger amount of acid than Cu catalysts on other supports (Fig. 4 ). Since the catalytic activity was increased with the addition of sodium, the catalyst performance was compared through CO temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) experiments. In the DMC synthesis, the CO adsorption capability on catalyst is thought to be inevitably related to the catalyst performance. Fig. 5 shows the profile of CO desorption of NH4-Y zeolite and Cu/Y-zeolite and Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalysts calcined at 550°C. CO desorption of NH4-Y zeolite occurred between 150 and 390°C and showed its the maximum value at 330°C. However, calcined Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalyst represents the active desorption of CO at 150°C. This result is almost in accordance with the activity results of Table 6. It is known that CO desorption has an important relation with the addition of Na during the DMC synthesis by the oxidative carbonylation of methanol. Addition of Na as cocatalyst showed a lower desorption temperature of carbon monoxide. Anderson [12] proposed that this CO addition to adsorbed methoxide species to form carbomethoxide species is rate determining step. 3.6 Oxidation state of the Cu/Na/Y-zeolite A XPS analysis was conducted to obtain information on the surface state of the Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalyst. Fig. 6 shows the XPS spectra for Cu 2p3/2 of dried Cu/Na/Y-zeolite and calcined Cu/Na/Y-zeolite. The XPS peaks of both catalysts were different in shape as well as intensity. This indicates that the bonding type and energy of Cu in the two catalysts might be different from each other. The curve-fitting results of Cu 2p XPS patterns on the Cu/Y-zeolite (dry) and Cu/Y-zeolite calcined at 500°C are compared in Fig. 6a and b. The Cu/Y-zeolite (dry) peak at 932.24eV represents the ClCuCl bond (Fig. 6a). The Cu/Y-zeolite (550°C) peak at 933.16eV was shifted (+)0.92eV. This peak at 933.16eV is attributed to the presence of Cu2+. The Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) was found to have two peaks, as shown in Fig. 6c. The first peak was found at 930.88eV and the second peak at 932.04eV. The first peak at 930.88eV is thought to be associated with Cu+. The second peak at 932.04eV was attributed to the presence of Cu2+. Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) was found to have one peak, as shown in Fig. 6a. However, Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C) differed, having two peaks, as shown in Fig. 6d. The intensity of the first peak at 930.88eV was stronger than that of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry). This phenomenon is due to an increase of Cu+ on the Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C) catalyst caused by the reduction of Cu2+. Tkachenko et al. demonstrated that the presence of Cu+ is explained by a shift of the surface equilibrium between Cu2+ and Cu+ in the presence of a high proton concentration with preferential stabilization of Cu+ [20]. (CuOH)+H+ +e− →Cu+ +H2O 3.7 Comparison of activity on various copper using XANES The state and coordination of Cu were confirmed by Cu K-edge XANES. As shown in Fig. 7 , the XANES spectra of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) and Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C) were compared with the spectra of reference compounds (CuCl2 and CuO). As shown in Fig. 7, the pre-edge peak of Cu2+ remained at the position of 8994eV. Changes in the XANES spectra for these samples were observed. The main peak of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) at 8994eV was shifted after calcinations. Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) exhibited a well-defined pre-edge peak at 8982eV and a peak maximum at 8994eV and Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C) exhibited a well-defined pre-edge peak at 8982eV and a peak maximum at 8996eV. The maximum peak of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) was similar to that of the reference compound (CuCl2) and the maximum peak of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C) was similar to the reference compound (CuO). The maximum peak was similar to activity to DMC. The low photon energy position of the maximum peak was the higher activity for the yield of DMC, as shown in Fig. 7a. The results of XANES revealed a difference of reactivity according to the state of the copper catalyst. Activity on the DMC yield of CuCl2 >Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry)>Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C)>Cu(OH)2 accorded with the maximum peak of the low photon energy position. 4 Conclusions Among various metal catalysts, copper chloride showed the highest activity and selectivity of DMC among Mg, Ca, Co, and Fe containing chlorides. Also, copper catalysts containing different anions were examined in terms of the conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC. Chlorine and bromine, having strong electron withdrawing power, provided high yields of DMC. Heterogeneous copper catalysts were applied in order to reduce the dissolution of the copper catalyst during the reaction. Among various supports, Y-zeolite yielded the best results on conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC. The addition of alkali hydroxides increased the conversion and selectivity without a promoter. Yield of DMC on the alkali metal was increased in the order Li+ <Na+ <K+, but the selectivity was in the order of Li+ >Na+ >K+. NaOH showed the best DMC yield. From a XRD analysis, the existence of crystal forms of copper chloride hydroxide was observed. TPD results showed an important relation with the addition of NaOH during DMC synthesis by the oxidative carbonylation of methanol. The addition of NaOH as a co-catalyst showed a lower desorption temperature of carbon monoxide. CO adsorption and desorption were the rate-determining step to activate methanol and form the DMC. Also, difference in the XPS spectra pattern between before and after calcinations was confirmed. The XPS peaks of the catalysts were different in shape as well as intensity, indicating that the bonding type and energy of Cu in the two catalysts might be different from each other. Cu/Na/Y-zeolite(dry) was found to have two peaks, as shown in Fig. 6c. The first peak was found at 930.88eV and the second peak at 932.04eV. The first peak at 930.88eV is thought to be associated with Cu+. The second peak at 932.04eV was attributed to the presence of Cu2+. Furthermore, the state and coordination of Cu were confirmed by Cu K-edge XANES. XANES showed the difference of reactivity according to the state of the copper catalyst. The activity on the DMC yield of CuCl2 >Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry)>Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C)>Cu(OH)2 was in accordance with the maximum peak of the low photon energy position. Acknowledgement This work was supported by Inter-Metropolitan Cooperation Development funded by the Presidential Committee on Regional Development (PCRD, Korea). References [1] P. Tundo M. Selva Acc. coredata.dc:description: The effects of various anions containing copper based catalysts were studied in regard to the preparation of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) through oxidative carbonylation of methanol under a liquid phase system. A copper compound providing the strong withdrawing power of halides as anion yielded excellent results with respect to the conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC. However, copper homogenous catalysts suffer from separation of the catalyst after reaction. Thus, the development of a new reaction system using various supports including Y-zeolite was attempted. The conversion of methanol and selectivity to DMC were affected by the properties of the supports. In particular, Y-zeolite showed the best yield among various supports. The influence of various promoters was examined with the aim of increasing the yield of DMC from methanol. The yield of DMC was increased with the addition of alkali metal in the order Li+ <Na+ <K+, but with selectivity in the order of Li+ >Na+ >K+, respectively. Various analyses were conducted in order to elucidate these results. From a XRD analysis, the existence of crystal forms of copper chloride hydroxide of Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry) was observed. We confirmed the presence of peaks of CuO in Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C). The CO-TPD analysis revealed that CO desorption is an important step to determine the formation of DMC. The addition of NaOH as a co-catalyst resulted in a lower desorption temperature of carbon monoxide in Cu catalyst. Also, XPS analysis results showed that Cu+ on the calcined Cu/Na/Y-zeolite catalyst was formed by the reduction of Cu2+. XANES results provided the difference of reactivity according to the state of the copper catalyst. Activity of this reaction in terms of DMC yields, obtained in the order of CuCl2 >Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (dry)>Cu/Na/Y-zeolite (550°C)>Cu(OH)2 was in accordance with the maximum peak of the low photon energy position.
coredata.dc:title: The influence of support in the synthesis of dimethyl carbonate by Cu-based catalysts
